results.title: Shoah: first era
results.creator_credit: Les Films Aleph and Claude Lanzmann
results.brief_description: Director Claude Lanzmann’s ‘Shoah’ (the Hebrew word for destruction or annihilation), attempts to create in the present the reality of the Holocaust through the memories of its survivors, both victims and perpetrators. This remarkable documentary achieves this without a single use of archival or found footage, rather letting the horror of the Holocaust resonate through the myriad of stories and the faces of the survivors. Lanzmann and his documentary crew take their subjects through the now abandoned fields and buildings of their past torment, as they recount and talk the viewer through the unknowable and unthinkable. Images such as disused train tracks, overgrown with grass and leading nowhere take on a chilling and profound resonance as we are left to contemplate what happened there. Winner of the 1985 New York Film Critics Circle Award and the 1985 National Society of Film Critics Awards-USA.

results.title: Shirt factory
results.brief_description: A reaction, expressed in dance and mime, to a school visit to the local shirt factory; a protest at the monotony of piece work. Adapted from an original stage production for an end of term concert at Markfield Secondary School, North London.

results.title: Shirley MacLaine's inner workout (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Higher Self Seminars and Michael Wiese
results.brief_description: There is no escaping stress in our world, that’s why “Shirley MacLaine’s inner workout” is such a breakthrough. It’s a workout for mind, body and soul that’s every bit as important as daily exercise. It’s a comprehensive workout using meditation and relaxation techniques practiced for centuries in the Orient. Each meditation focuses on specific emotional areas such as creativity, control, love, sexuality, power, communication, judgement and more.

results.title: Shipyard
results.brief_description: An outstanding early British documentary made by Rotha and sponsored by the Orient line. Remarkable for its fine photography and editing techniques especially the use of combined dissolves and superimposition to develop two associated ideas simultaneously (influenced by early Soviet filmmaking principles). Describes the building of the steamship “Orion” at Barrow-in-Furness and its economic effects on the life of the town, making particularly effective use of the local dialect (the film unit were noted for their attempt to show the working class under a positive light). Written and edited by Paul Rotha; photography by George Pocknall, Frank Bundy, Frank Goodliffe and Harry Rignold.

results.title: Shipwrecked a True Story
results.creator_credit: Bill Bennett Productions, Dick Smith Adventure and Bill Bennett
results.brief_description: On April 15th, 1978, Bill Belcher, lone yachtsman in a race from New Zealand to Australia, was shipwrecked. His self-designed and built craft was wrecked on a coral atoll some 600 kilometres from the coast of Australia. From that time, until his rescue on May 13th, Bill survived in an inflatable rubber life raft. This is the recreated story of his extraordinary experience.

results.creator_credit: Rank Organisation Film Productions, Ian Latimer and Daniel Ingram

results.title: Ships at work
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Malcolm Otton and Christopher Cordeaux
results.brief_description: A small boy finding himself on board a tugboat, learns about the different parts of the ship, and the various functions of other types of ships - dredges, tankers, cargo ships, and a hydrofoil. Explains different loading methods for wheat, wool, coal, oil, and cars. Tells where the goods are from and their destinations.

results.title: Shipmates
results.brief_description: Emily brings her friends home to the Cape Otway Lighthouse for her twelfth birthday. Her fisherman friend Jack gives her a model of the “Loch Ard” one of the clipper ships which foundered on the coast. Jack is keen to catch the tagged fish which will win him a new boat. But the “Loch Ard” has plans of its own. Rated: G

results.title: Shipbuilding in Australia
results.brief_description: A brief history of the shipbuilding industry in Australia, and a record of the designing, building, launching and trials of an Australian ship. Includes the initial planning by the designer; the steel stockyard, building berth and fitting berth; and the slip-way where the ship is constructed and launched, and after which all the fittings such as radar, wireless, and rigging are installed. Also sea trials and handing over.
